discourse_list.title: Addendum for MIP72: Delegated Collateral Attachment - RWA Arranger Application - 6s Capital

content.content: 6s Capital’s Motivation: 6s Capital, as a commercial lender, wishes to expand its lending operations and bring on new staff to cover the Clean Money Initiative and wants comfort that credit will be available for such lending activities. With a broader approved scope, 6s Capital can then focus on growing its lending operations within that scope, raising the needed institutional equity, running the operations, being in compliance with the Credit Agreements, and engaging with governance. Crawl. Walk. Run. - Part 1. Part 2. Part 3. Part 4. With MIP72, it is 6s’ hope that other participants engage with the DAO and follow the path that 6s has set forth to also be a non-bank operating commercial lender. We need more LendCOs. What does an “Arranger” do? In summary, an arranger is a DAO-empowered role that causes real-world commerce while doing so with “checks and balances” based on a framework and scope / authorization approved by the DAO. Further, this role is one that should “rise-above” the legal nuances (leaving those for licensed experts) and focus on core implementation, construct deals, and cause commerce.  General Context, Motivation, and Background: The DAO is composed of various members spanning the globe, each with a unique skill set and contribution to Maker. While the DAO is relatively young, it has grown to now utilize external collateral as well as digital collateral. Such collateral must be properly attached (in both digital and “real-world” forms). Attached in this context means a construct that would allow for a senior lien foreclosure in a court of law. To protect itself, the DAO must approach attaching various forms of collateral with humility and always yield to trusted external experts that have industry experience in securing said collateral.  Certainty Lenders (all of them) revolve on certainty. The business of a lender is lending money to others. The first responsibility of a lender is to know they have a source of money to lend. Before even allocating the resources to start engaging with would-be borrowers (regardless of scope), they rely / thrive / require certainty they can execute, while operating within certain boundaries. Reputation and ability to “do what you say” is paramount, as well as contractual obligations to do so. Once onboarded, engaging with the DAO must not gate transaction capability.  Monolithic vs Modular There are various implementation techniques to allow for attaching collateral in the real-world (especially evolving to new collateral).  Monolithic Structure On first pass, the inclination is to just amend the existing Credit Agreement over and over. In this context we would have the world’s most extensive and broad credit agreement (and associated security agreement) to encompass a known scope without knowing how to properly attach each underlying collateral. When a borrower agrees to a blanket lien, it is paramount to be able to secure all associated collateral. It is illogical to assume we will know before we engage with a would-be borrower each type of collateral and have received governance approval for the legal language to attach each type. Each collateral type would have to be described and referenced in a document that would be in a state of being “ever-amended” (with each amendment needing governance to approve). While conceptually possible, the notion of a monolithic solution is referenced to contrast why a modular strategy is superior in every conceivable way.  Modular Structure By utilizing a Delaware Series LLC (aka a segregated portfolio company in other jurisdictions), an unlimited number of registered Series each legally isolated from the other may be created. Each series would have its own equity and its own debt. Thus each Series within the LendCo would then have its own Credit Agreement tailored to the specific type of collateral to be attached or even more broadly per project. In addition or alternatively, a wholly owned newly formed Delaware LLC may be substutied for a new Series as the case may be.  0UzDldt9u1ujx7s2J4RQHYqlZXGixDhSMQG3oMFLgxeFidrwJLjq5mArD4zNpkrZeXxrx9zoaZI2m35vF1YmvGSdHB8-RJpDNXlJ1Y-0H1dCPYhNGCf2m_zx4hobtDSaCq7FXO8b1600×900 157 KB   4haQyQblyCyIdqoPJXBh9H2nOxbKYPFJISbFhRdi32l6G69cd2KiW7vgPuJBMrXi0nRdUAfJzc5DBzkcqSkrWuuDA1XiJ-cYPGn528WCzOcaSoSkKyZbFwcCAfVSshfKfi53iHsG960×540 42.7 KB   FxeCKK01rlA7_cZGvoRoDsuJuOVxGwlKCC3qMB6FSpQXpxJQGfg3kia-3PuXzg0rs4_ErOYgoQECEc-VbrIfaCFv_u1i22mDrozhl7O7egm6LSm8GaX9o5DML3skKGCVFICnWQ7E1600×900 133 KB   FBbxUv-hb4go5SE5yNOAZqt58gwl3GExFXw9D9pjlfwPuRsuyeB1VJ9Ez8EFz1bQr-C1AdZZwFyABF90hgvvrcHbEHnUmkdYeMoa406UTuBOzZX0WuWoXrwFREBOHB8jNCkCnCpy1600×900 178 KB   OfN-nhO8jI2BZ0O2DmQFfg9atrM-6QqT7EsFlpioBvRW4BxyA1GcmdubNGEblgC3mJqzv1_QUPavhUdI9Sy-w8JJ-Ex_lpRBAlHRt-2-3YKuQBO08p5uivkL-0z8adfV8MZ4mPeg1600×900 153 KB   H4MGcHRMcdvUQsG6KZuPQNAoDk6gLbjo6AFKH521rQ6K8T-41AAmsWc3_7jhSTB5HFo0r27Xz9Pft-G38pqroL00iUsJLrc35sZerwV1KVJ_aGLVtnwYlBCvVGL1FIUdtO4JcM3v1600×909 156 KB   LtGNkFh3_TH3WwOcotOQOc59OwGEud5K3CvLfPJUi-o1K7ZbkNUTAHoIeyvmG2PeOK6BHqw9wwnMYpHrv6Fxly4FlkmD49m12Ed_acTsc0W2tjfd_cFC09OBtmsGrD_ojK20wE4F1600×888 172 KB   1uaqaUZXEZ-L2AO3B7yE1bCbye_igS_HgB9lZc34GG2zNUrQXAEnJ-j--3kOyG5WNguoo7mFcoOIZSwUmoMy3djZZIJXEEp9l7hxELWrfw1Z9QDoSCf3W22PqZn4atSWa4XJb9CL1600×900 198 KB   MQWKFVc9S8Q0AHy0eXUdF3gTIGl6fkASZNtizevzPl6T2H2HkT0pnL_MEMVL3T0p3gS0C6Jr5SVDfU3G3ucKKesT4nvhgjYciK92OwP_JXvtjppNH4MmwphI5bVrXLhidmJtHV8u1600×900 170 KB   _CrT2G_gTWgBIziRUT8lCXCAODZ2-znIQgj2u85blYxnmZ4R6TYVUGnWwk4a3xrOdTmirjMxWlo_fQ-LbeDrp3HSHxY2gDXjY94H0g3_REQTrAQcUpvhgX6CbpUtW2jJpmjO1Uy11600×900 123 KB   Why is this important In a monolithic credit agreement design, the agreement would be in an ever-present state of amendment to properly define the type of collateral (same with the security agreement). Each amendment would then need governance’s approval. As presently implemented, each new transaction (if the collateral did not attach the same as the others) would then require a LendCo to approach the DAO for a governance approval. Given the non-standard nature of collateral onboarding in the private credit space, this creates uncertainty for LendCo and LendCo’s customers and would likely create delays that could cause LendCo’s services to be less attractive than traditional lenders. From a practical standpoint, this is operationally impossible as properly securing each collateral type (outside of real estate) would then need amendments and put the DAO in a perpetual state of governance approvals of legal documents. It is our belief that overloaded governance cannot lead to good governance. Further, raising equity for such a monolithic design is problematic as some equity investors want specific collateral segregation and certainty around liquidation to be more defined before they will invest. The existing Credit Agreement and Security Agreement that the DAO has seen covers one specific type of real estate collateral. Given the scope of the DAO’s future credit activities (including the Clean Money initiative), it will be necessary for the DAO to permit not only additional types of real estate collateral (commercial, industrial, multi-family, infrastructure, conservation, agriculture, etc.) but also other assets which are part of, or necessary to, such real estate projects (e.g., equipment, receivables, leases). Each of these “real-world” collateral types has different characteristics that must be covered in one or several new credit agreements and security agreements. Put bluntly, one size does not fit all.  Impossible to predict all use cases It is simply impossible for a senior secured lender with an expanded scope to know or draft (ex-ante) all potential use cases into one credit agreement. For example, how does one attach fishing rights in Florida as collateral? Or power purchase agreements with an Iowa utility company? While these examples are assets that might be used, one can imagine the cognitive load for LendCOs to continually approach the DAO for contract approvals or amendments, let alone considering the DAOs ability to properly evaluate such legal contracts.  Knowledge and expertise In addition to the above point of not knowing all potential use cases, certain collateral must be attached differently based on standard commercial practice. That is to say the DAO can and will learn how to properly attach collateral in many jurisdictions over time. Today however it is largely blind on how to properly do so, consistent with Delaware law or other U.S. / Canadian laws. The DAO would be far better protected to authorize a well-defined and well-documented scope and let industry experts structure, draft, and implement multiple credit agreements that attach collateral specifically rather than stumble through (and most certainly make mistakes that are easily avoidable by yielding to the Trust’s legal counsel for both engaging with an ethics bound counterparty and providing the comfort of proper legal drafting). No different than the CEOs of two companies negotiating and agreeing on a term sheet. Neither will draft (or possibly even read) the nuanced legal documents, each will delegate that authority and responsibility to his / her legal team to ensure the underlying transaction documents are consistent with the term sheet (and are enforceable under applicable law). The DAO urgently needs to implement such a mentality.  Legitimacy A DAO can empower individuals to complete certain tasks. Further the DAO can grant authority. The DAO cannot however grant legitimacy or industry knowledge. Specifically for how to properly attach and secure collateral, the DAO should not empower mandated actors (or their teams) to learn / gate / approve this, as the “real world” already knows how to do this and will >> always << do it better. Rather, the DAO should rely on the intentional feedback loop with an Attester (or an Established Legitimate Party) and the Trust’s & Trustee’s legal counsel and not waste cognitive load on the legal minutia and debates by non-attorneys. The DAO needs to instead focus on the business terms and assess the overall risk of the Term Sheet (with the requirements outlined therein e.g. senior secured lien with a first-loss equity requirement), and which mandates it wishes to implement (and the area of debate and consensus).  RWA Attester and Portfolio Core Unit When working together in concert, an Attester & Established Legitimate Party alongside the Portfolio core unit provide a potent collaboration tool the DAO can rely upon. They in-effect annually “certify” an Arranger / LendCo to operate within a Delegated Collateral Attachment credit authorization from the DAO. This is important as each operates to accomplish uniquely collaborative components. Ensuring known quality of underwriting is being performed at the LendCo level and all underlying agreements, including the drafting of the Credit Agreement(s). To that end, no one should approve an Arranger / LendCo, less MakerDAO. Rather an Attester should “certify” them as compliant. (e.g. Not Rejected does not equal an Approval). As an Attester or an Established Legitimate Party must be pulled into the process during the drafting / pre-closing of any new credit agreement, a full circle feedback loop is created as a result to ensure quality and compliance. The DAO must clearly delineate the private entanglement of DAO actors (Core Units) from Arrangers; this is most pronounced when documents are being drafted pre-closing with 6s’ legal counsel and legal counsel of WSFS (which represents both the trust and the trustee) along with input from an Established Legitimate Party. This separation of powers is an important prudent discipline to ingrain in the ethos of how we do Arrangers. Private entanglement is a slippery slope that can cause real problems and can be addressed and mitigated if implemented at the beginning. WSFS’ requirement of common counsel for both the trustee and the trust was driven because the DAO cannot be represented by counsel.  Established Legitimate Party As further outlined in the sub proposal hereinbelow, the concept of a Established Legitimate Party is a private (non-DAO Core Unit) actor that must be ratified by the DAO who has the responsibility to ensure that any Credit Agreement that 6s assembles is consistent with the authorization outlined herein. To start, the first Established Legitimate Party will be RWA Company LLC. It is fully expected that Party may retain counsel to “speak the same language” and interpret the markups of the drafts. To the extent it is useful, this process may also be done with non-confidential / redacted copies being published. Further, it is fully expected that other Observers may also do the same. 6s welcomes input in the drafting stage. One can imagine in the future large fully established firms (e.g. Ernst & Young) participate in this capacity.  Equity buffer for risk mitigation In addition to attaching collateral properly for a variety of use cases, each credit agreement would continue to have affirmative equity covenants (at both the company and series level). LendCos must raise equity to fill the first-loss position (or junior capital). To do so, a LendCo is faced with two fundamental decisions, pursue equity that will accept a “peanut butter” approach in covering all collateral types OR equity wanting exposure to a specific type of collateral, leading to multiple Series each with different collateral types, each with its own credit agreement. The choice of how equity is raised is a strategic decision that should not concern the DAO, less it just has to be there. Rather anything that helps the LendCo raise that loss equity, indirectly helps the DAO, by mitigating its risk of loss. While either approach is possible, equity investors (especially institutional) will most probably opt for the latter as they want and need to price their risk and liquidation position with collateral they can understand (e.g. they may not want their preferred equity investment to have exposure to both wind power generation and a water desalination plant if they are energy investors). Without the above, the ability for LendCo to have a broad scope and raise equity is a challenging exercise. Moreover, given the SEC disclosure requirements for a U.S. equity offering, the required disclosures could either be too vague or so detailed that the offering document is hundreds of pages long. From a MakerDAO risk perspective, there is no downside to authorizing multiple credit agreements provided they function materially and legally the same as the existing credit agreement, allow collateral (all types) to be properly secured to the Trust AND allow LendCOs to more effectively and efficiently raise the first-loss equity buffer needed.  Moving the cognitive load For no other reason than safety and to ensure a senior secured structure is maintained with a variety of collateral types, the DAO should move the cognitive legal review load from the DAO to where it is best suited: the trustee, trust and their counsel. The DAO already “Trusts the Trust” to hold cash and liens. The DAO should delegate and extend that same confidence in their ability to ensure legal documents are drafted correctly to properly secure the collateral consistent with traditional institutional commercial transactions (provided a feedback loop is implemented, trust but verify). While it is a directed Trust, the Trustee can acknowledge DAO instructions (which are legally permissible and will not harm the Trustee) that are / will be relayed by the Trust Sponsor to the Trustee.  Will the DAO ever be able to gain the experience to properly know how to attach all collateral? Possibly. Should the DAO try, yes. Should the DAO always yield to experts, Absolutely! How does one attach fishing rights as collateral in Florida? Or aircraft in Oklahoma? The DAO will struggle to know, but experienced law firms already know how to do it better, safer, and faster. Period. Always. The DAO should focus on taking strategic decisions about the broad risk pools and sectors it wants exposure to. This should be done during the proposal approval process. Today the DAO does the same with attaching digital assets and rightfully delegates that authority to the Protocol Engineering team as not all ERC-20s are the same. Instead of relying on DAO nominated parties, we should use licensed attorneys that represent the Trust to the DAO’s favor (as MakerDAO is the beneficiary), as they have the legal obligation to act in the best interests of their client as well having a Established Legitimate Party review during the drafting phase.  How do we handle the stability fee / risk pricing? As each credit agreement has (and will have) reporting requirements that LendCo must fulfill (or else be in breach), parties like RWA Company LLC (and other-nominated, and mutually-agreed upon, Observers) will see the precise list of loans (and all underlying transactional documents, including the underwriting), made per Credit Agreement. (The process to add / remove / replace Observers is further outlined in the sub-process outlined below.) As most of the lending risk can be computed from the financial ratios associated with a given loan, the portfolio of loans could then be priced after each reporting window. Further as more technological advances are made (e.g. a platform for RWA Company) an almost real-time information flow can be achieved for the risk-team to further evaluate and price the risk of underlying loans and allow for proper asset liability evaluation. That said, the more equity that is added to a portfolio (e.g. credit enhancement), the less risk for the senior secured creditor. This proposal includes a Stability Fee pricing design to allow for a hybrid of a treasury management buffer / capital battery at the Trust. For example, when the RWA001-A vault is set low (e.g. 0 bps), capital would be held in US Treasuries until such time as it is later deployed pursuant via the credit authorization outlined herein to LendCo, where the cost of capital will be a (RWA001-A + DSR) or 200 bps, whichever is higher. This creates a cost of capital floor to LendCo. This is important as it provides an elegant dual-purpose mechanism to unwind any treasury capital battery positions at the Trust without impacting LendCo and yet also allows the DAO to take full advantage of a Delaware Statutory Trust with an institutional regulated Trustee holding cash (or US Treasuries) with institutional safeguards in place >>> regardless of capital balance <<< . The DAO started off with using senior secured commercial real estate as the first collateral to properly and securely attach. While by and large this will remain the majority of collateral for the immediate short-term, the DAO should not constrain itself to one form only. The DAO must learn. To do so, it must iterate and have industry experts opine and draft different documents that attach different types of collateral. There is no better way for that skill and knowledge to come to the DAO than for an Arranger / LendCo wanting to attach new collateral, and showing the world how to do it. Thus far, we have had to wait on parties to approach the DAO. This will not scale well. However, based on this proposal, a would-be borrower could approach a LendCo with a new unique type of collateral (that is in the clean money scope for example). LendCo could then either set up a new series (or form a wholly owned newly formed Delaware LLC), or utilize an existing one, without changing the risk profile to the DAO or burdening it with cognitive load. Should that LendCo or the Trustee determine that, to properly secure and attach a new form of collateral, a new credit agreement is needed, it would engage with the Trustee and enter into a new credit agreement and the DAO would always see the conformed versions and would learn. This last feedback loop is essential. Quite similar to how the SEC Edgar filings are public, seeing the underlying contracts for new collateral (its description and how it was attached) is a critical part of how the DAO will learn with time. The DAO does not possess (nor should it) the ability to run so many credit agreements while this is precisely what a trustee is built for. The DAO should leverage service providers and their legal expertise to ensure collateral is securely and properly attached and the covenants (financial / reporting / other requirements) are in each credit agreement. A compliance framework / feedback loop is an essential part of properly safeguarding the DAO to report any “out of compliance” events.  The spirit of the AAVE D3M but for RWA While not intended to technically replicate the Direct Deposit DAI module, there are many similarities that are worth noting. With the Aave D3M, the DAO is pricing the risk associated with Aave’s ability to be a DAI distribution point, thus the obligation to properly secure such DAI with collateral has been delegated to Aave (and its engineers). Further, the DAO gains economies of scale by outsourcing many functions to known counterparties. As the DAO now prices the Aave D3M risk on aggregate, the analysis can then be consolidated. One can imagine a Compound D3M (or the next upcoming D3M) and the analysis needed becomes more manageable instead of the DAO managing the risk directly. That is to say, the DAO can focus on the risk associated with the portfolio of collateral, not the implementation of how to securely attach the collateral. This MIP is intended to largely replicate the operational spirit of the D3M but for RWAs and utilize a trusted institutional counterparty (the Trustee), that is both independent and regulated, and its counsel to handle and ensure credit agreements and security agreements are properly drafted / enforceable / secured in nature. With this we allow for a delegated collateral attachment approach for credit with an approved lending scope. This enables scale, not only for LendCo, but for the many other LendCOs that follow this path.  Hardware vs. Software Another analogy that may further crystallize the thinking would be to evaluate how to get additional functionality out of a given device that is planning on running an important function. In all scenarios, the hardware specifications must be known to evaluate the safety. Subsequent functionality can either deploy new hardware that requires re-evaluation of the hardware requirement each time, or use a known authoritative update server that can be designed to update the software on the existing hardware. Clearly the latter makes sense and scales better for new functionality. In this context, the existing Trust, Broker/Dealer, MIP21 are all hardware. They are known (Trust enforceability opinion) and verified (circuit test). The credit agreements and security agreements for new collateral are the software. The Trust’s and Trustee’s counsel are the authoritative server that provides the updates constrained to the scope. The objective of the hardware was “to get the dollars to Delaware.” Once there, held protected in a bankruptcy remote Delaware Statutory Trust, the software (the Credit Agreements and general corporate commerce) is then a known quantity where over the last 100+ years seasoned legal experts have perfected the ability to properly secure collateral with legal documents.  What power does the DAO retain? Regardless of what collateral credit arrangements the DAO authorizes, the DAO will >> always << retain power over the following:  Debt Ceiling (the aggregate for all credit agreements constructed from the Trust → 6s) - Settning to zero impedes all downstream cash deploment Stability Fee  As designed, prior to any release of capital from the Trust, the Credit Agreements require the Verification Agent, Wilmington Savings Fund Society, to verify sufficient debt ceiling capacity remains before allowing credit to be released. Therefore, if the DAO wants to stop all lending activities, it needs only vote the debt ceiling to zero, and absolutely all subsequent lending activities downstream will come to a halt. Similarly, the DAO may change the interest rates that impact the downstream credit agreements as outlined in the term sheet. Finally, the DAO can reduce the debt ceiling to zero which will cease all lending and cause all collateral to be orderly paid-down across >> all << credit agreements. The above was designed to replicate the DSS as closely as possible but using the existing legal system.  Operational Leverage Under the assumption (and hope) that there will be many more LendCOs that approach the DAO similar to 6s (e.g. Arrangers), the DAO would be well-served to adopt the above delegated collateral attachment approach to allow for tens or hundreds of LendCOs while maintaining a flat quantity of Established Legitimate Party to handle this scale. While unlikely, it is imperative that the Arranger model / framework function in a sustainable resilient manner. We must even contemplate the scenario that the DAO one day has no core units, as the only thing constant with a DAO will be change. Certification of compliance with reputable parties (e.g. at minimum a Trustee and then others) must be built-in. By default, an arranger could always publish a redacted Borrower Compliance Certificate per Credit Agreement per quarter (Exhibit F of the Credit Agreement) in the forum to demonstrate compliance and rely on the Trustee. The objective being that operational leverage would then allow risk teams to focus on the portfolio of collateral rather than the implementation thereof. Should this proposal be accepted, the community should expect that it will take 6s months of effort of engagement with equity participants as well as borrowers in different collateral sectors before any material capital is deployed. The current bootstrapped credit tenant lease (commercial real-estate) will continue to be the baseload loan origination space as new loans originated for other sectors come online. Under a credit agreement, there will be activity that was not anticipated when the agreement was signed. For example, the credit agreement may state that a lien under $1,000 is not a default. Be what if the lien is $1,050. Does it make business sense to declare a default and terminate the credit agreement over $50? Probably not. To address unknowns, a credit agreement will typically provide for (1) a cure period, (2) a waiver and/or (3) an amendment. Most events can be easily and quickly cured. In this example, paying off the lien cures the default. In other cases, actions cannot be undone and must be waived if the parties wish to continue under a given credit agreement. Other events may require waivers over and over and should instead be addressed by an amendment, so the event is not a constantly recurring default (if that is the agreement for the parties). This last option requires the affirmative vote of MakerDAO. In this context with the structure implemented, the Directors have the responsibility to make the final decision on if they grant a reasonable waiver for commercial agreements (as requested by the US Trust) that are in the best interest of the Trust. For example, a mechanics lien is a breach of a Credit Agreement (for good reason) but unlike code, life happens. Mechanics liens are common business practice in various jurisdictions to protect workers’ rights to ensure payment. Should a mechanics lien occur (which is also a breach of the end-end borrower’s loan agreement), 6s will pursue a remedy with the end borrower to ensure the borrower resolves the underlying dispute and have the lien removed. Sometimes, a waiver should be granted when it is in the best interests of all parties involved. Scenarios like a report being two days late on one occasion or a tax filing that has been reported and is being dealt with by a borrower should not cause a liquidation event. This is common best practice, though impossible to code. Any Director as part of their legal duties must understand the legal implications of such a waiver request. Independent Directors were selected specifically as a neutral professional was and will always be needed. Because of the power Directors have with regard to the above, they must have integrity (which is to say they do the right thing when no-one is watching) and comply with the statutory legal duties of a director. Given the legal exposure for the Directors, they would have no reason to waive any defaults unless such was in the best interest of the Trust, as they have a fiduciary responsibility. The process of influencing that decision-making of last resort is and will always be an iterative process to which the RWA International Advisory Committee (with a sub-proposal hereinbelow) is being created to provide recommendations, and MakerDAO-context where otherwise there might be a vacuum, to the Directors. While only a first step, we look forward to collaborating with the MakerDAO community / Real World Finance team / other to refine this engagement with time.
